'''E.G. Kight''' (born January 17, 1966) is an American [[Chicago blues]] singer, guitarist and songwriter.  She has worked with many musicians including [[George Jones]], [[Jerry Lee Lewis]], [[Conway Twitty]], [[Merle Haggard]], [[Luther Allison]], [[Hubert Sumlin]], [[Pinetop Perkins]], [[Taj Mahal (musician)|Taj Mahal]], [[B.B. King]], and [[Koko Taylor]].<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Kight"/> Kight has recorded seven albums to date, and received a number of [[Blues Music Award]]s nominations for both contemporary female artist, and song of the year.<ref name="AMG"/> 

Kight is billed as the 'Georgia Songbird'.<ref name="Oldies"/> Her main musical influence was Koko Taylor.<ref name="AMG"/>

==Life and career==
'''Eugenia Gail Kight''' was born in [[Dublin, Georgia]], United States, and at the age of five was taught to play the guitar by her grandmother.<ref name="AMG"/> In her youth she watched [[Elvis Presley]] perform in [[Macon, Georgia]].<ref name="Knox"/> Initially raised on a musical diet of [[gospel music|gospel]] and [[country music|country]], she graduated towards the [[blues]] after hearing a [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] of [[Koko Taylor]].  Already a professional musician in her mid-teens, Kight moved away from playing country songs and began her career in [[Chicago blues]]. She appeared regularly on ''[[Nashville Now]]'' in 1989, and toured extensively in the late 1990s and into the new millennium.<ref name="Oldies"/><ref name="Knox">{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.knoxville.com/news/2013/jan/11/knoxville-music-eg-kight-second-harvest-benefit/ |title=There's a lot more to EG Kight than just the blues |publisher=Knoxville.com |date=2013-01-11 |accessdate=2013-03-25}}</ref>

Her 1997 album, ''Come into the Blues'', included a version of "[[I've Been Loving You Too Long]]." In 2002, she performed at the ceremony when a statue of the song's writer, [[Otis Redding]] was unveiled at the [[Georgia Music Hall of Fame]]. The same year, Blue South Records released ''Trouble''. ''Southern Comfort'' followed the next year,<ref name="AMG"/> and had piano work from [[Chuck Leavell]] plus her cover of [[John Prine]]'s "[[Angel from Montgomery]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/southern-comfort-mw0000028728/credits |title=Southern Comfort - E.G. Kight : Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-03-25}}</ref>

In 2004, she released ''Takin' It Easy'', which along with her own compositions included [[cover version]]s of [[Duke Ellington]]'s "[[I Ain't Got Nothin' But the Blues]]," and [[the Allman Brothers Band]]' "Southbound." Guest musicians on the album were [[Ann Rabson]], Chris Hicks ([[the Marshall Tucker Band]]), and Greg Piccolo (formerly with [[Roomful of Blues]]).<ref name="AMG"/> In the same year she was nominated for three Blues Music Awards.<ref name="Oldies"/>

On Kight's 2008 album, ''It's Hot in Here'', released by M.C. Records, the bulk of the tracks were either written or co-written by her.<ref name="AMG"/> It attained number one on the root blues chart and on [[Sirius XM Radio]].<ref name="Kight"/>

Prior to Kight's latest album release, ''Lip Service'' (2011), she had two stays in hospital due to a combination of [[meningitis]] and [[encephalitis]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://bluesrevue.com/2011/08/blues-bytes-%E2%80%93-eg-kight-part-two-8-05-11/# |title=Blues Bytes – EG Kight Part Two |publisher=Blues Revue |date=2011-08-05 |accessdate=2013-03-25}}</ref><ref name="Revue">{{cite web|author= |url=http://bluesrevue.com/2011/07/blues-bytes-eg-kight-part-one-7-29-11/# |title=Blues Bytes – EG Kight Part One |publisher=Blues Revue |date=2011-07-28 |accessdate=2013-03-25}}</ref> The album again had musical and [[record producer|production]] input from [[Paul Hornsby]], and also a tribute to Taylor with "Koko's Song".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/lip-service-mw0002154158/credits |title=Lip Service - E.G. Kight : Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-03-25}}</ref><ref name="Word">{{cite web|url=http://irom.wordpress.com/2011/11/28/cd-review-eg-kights-lip-service/ |title=CD Review: EG Kight’s “Lip Service” | The International Review of Music |publisher=Irom.wordpress.com |date=2011-11-28 |accessdate=2013-03-25}}</ref> In addititon, ''Lip Service'' incorporated Kight's duet with [[John Németh]].<ref name="Revue"/>

Her songs have been recorded by Taylor, [[Dorothy Moore]], [[Saffire – The Uppity Blues Women]], and [[Shakura S'Aida]].<ref name="Oldies"/>  She endorses [[Taylor Guitars]].<ref name="Kight">{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.egkight.com/bio/bioindex.html |title=EG Kight / The Biography |publisher=Egkight.com |date= |accessdate=2013-03-25}}</ref> Kight continues to live in Dublin, Georgia, on land that has belonged to her family for four generations.<ref name="Revue"/>
